questions.text: A 23 year old female came with complaints of dysphagia and hoarseness of voice and neck swelling. Radiological evaluation revealed a mass compressing the trachea. Biopsy revealed amyloid deposits with round regular cells surrounding it. What is the origin of cells?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Parafollicular C cell Amyloid rich stroma is a classical finding of Medullary thyroid cancer. These arise from parafollicular/C cells.

Highyeild:

MEDULLARY THYROID CANCER Arises from Parafollicular C cells. (Secrete Calcitonin) Can be Sporadic or Familial - MEN 2A or MEN2B(Associated with RET protooncogene). PRESENTATION Thyroid swelling - Most common Diarrhoea- Most Common in Familial MTC Enzymes and Hormones Released in MTC : Calcitonin Tumor marker for MTC : most sensitive marker for Recurrence CEA- Most specific marker of prognosis PG Serotonin- Reason for Diarrhea ACTH Mode of Spread: Lymphatic- Most Common BloodMets- MC site Liver > Bone(Osteoblastic) Characteristic Histology : Amyloid Stroma - Calcitonin Histology of medullary carcinoma showing characteristic 'cell balis' and amyloid (courtesy of Dr SWB Ewen, Aberdeen, UK).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Hurthle cell tumours are a rare variant of follicular neoplasm in which oxyphil (Hurthle, Ashkenazy) cells predominate histologically. Option: B. Follicular cell seen in Follicular thyroid cancer. Option: D. Askanazy cells predominate in Hurthle cells neoplasms.

questions.text: A 40 year old female recently diagnosed with breast cancer was advised for an ER screening test. Which class of marker does ER belong to?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prognostic marker Most important prognosis factor in metastatic or Advanced breast cancer is ER/PR > Her 2 Neu > Grade.

Highyeild:

MOLECULAR CLASSIFICATION OF BREAST CANCER ER PR Her2neu Ki67 Luminal A ● Most common subtype ● Best prognosis + + - Low Luminal B(Majority) + + + Low/High Luminal B (minority) + + - High Basal Type ● Triple negative ● Worst prognosis ● Cytokeratin ⅚ positive - - - High Her 2 neu enriched - - + Low/High Claudin low ● Cytokeratin ⅚ negative - - - High

questions.text: A patient presented with ulcer over the breast associated with erythema of surrounding skin and history of retraction of nipple, according to 8th edition of AJCC classification, which of the following statement is true:

options.label: D
options.text: Stage 4, if lymph node status N1-N3

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage 3B Erythema of surrounding skin is peau d orange which is extensive , hence it is T4D stage. According to 8th AJCC classification, it will be stage IIIB.

Highyeild:

BREAST CANCER AJCC ANATOMIC STAGE GROUPS Stage Tumor Node Metastasis 0 Tis N0 M0 IA T1 N0 M0 IB T0 N1mi M0 T1 N1mi M0 IIA T0 N1 M0 T1 N1 M0 T2 N0 M0 IIB T2 N1 M0 T3 N0 M0 IIIA T0 N2 M0 T1 N2 M0 T2 N2 M0 T3 N1 M0 T3 N2 M0 IIIB T4 N0 M0 T4 N1 M0 T4 N2 M0 IIIC AnyT N3 M0 IV AnyT AnyN M1

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- All other options are wrong.

questions.text: Extra esophageal manifestation of GERD: Asthma Laryngitis Pulmonary fibrosis Excessive phlegm Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A, B, C, D All of the following mentioned above are the extraesophageal manifestations of GERD.

Highyeild:

COMPLICATIONS OF GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE ESOPHAGEAL COMPLICATIONS Erosive esophagitis Esophageal stricture Barrett’s esophagus Esophageal cancer EXTRAESOPHAGEAL COMPLICATIONS Non cardiac chest pain Ear, nose and throat complications Globus sensation Pharyngitis Sinusitis Otitis Hoarseness Laryngitis Vocal cord granulomas Subglottic stenosis Laryngeal cancerDental erosions. Pulmonary complications Chronic cough Asthma Chronic bronchitis Pulmonary fibrosis Aspiration pneumonia Sleep apnea

questions.text: A 25 year old male complains of difficulty in swallowing food and weight loss. He also says there is regurgitation of undigested food and halitosis after meals. Barium swallow is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Achalasia cardia Above image shows bird beak appearance and it is seen in achalasia cardia.

Highyeild:

ACHALASIA CARDIA Failure of LES to relax due to Loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in myenteric and Auerbach plexus of esophagus. Clinical features Classical triad of achalasia- Dysphagia, Regurgitation and weight loss. Earliest and most common symptom- Regurgitation. Dysphagia- Initially liquids> solids. Nocturnal coughing Complications- aspiration pneumonitis. (Most common). Investigations Gold standard- Manometry. Barium swallow- Bird’s beak appearance.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Esophageal cancer has rat tail appearance on barium swallow. Option: C. An esophageal stricture refers to the abnormal narrowing of the esophageal lumen; it often presents as dysphagia, commonly described by patients as difficulty swallowing. Option: D. Barrett's esophagus is metaplasia of squamous to columnar epithelium. Endoscopic biopsy shows red velvety mucosa.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hepatitis B Hepatitis B has low association with development of cholangiocarcinoma out of all the options. Moreover it is mainly associated with development of intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

Highyeild:

RISK FACTORS FOR CHOLANGIOCARCINOMA Chronic inflammatory conditions Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) Oriental cholangiohepatitis Hepatitis C infection Parasitic infections Opisthorchis wverrini Clonorchis sinensis Congenital Choledochal cysts Caroll's disease Chemical agents Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast) Vinyl chloride Dioxin Asbestos Post surgical Biliary-enteric anastomosis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B,C,D. All other options are significant risk factors for the development of cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which is the most common hernia in females?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Indirect inguinal Most common hernia overall in females and overall is indirect inguinal hernia.

Highyeild:

Any hernia that comes through the Hasselbach’s triangle is called Direct inguinal hernia. Any hernia that comes lateral to this triangle is called Indirect inguinal hernia. HASSELBACH’S TRIANGLE BOUNDARIES Medial- Outer border of Rectus. Inferior- Inguinal ligament. Superior- Inferior epigastric vessels.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Direct inguinal is not the most common hernia in females. Option: C. Femoral hernia in itself is common in females , but most common hernia in females is indirect inguinal hernia. Option: D. Obturator hernia is not the most common hernia in females.

questions.text: The instruments shown below are used for which of the following procedures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy Above image is of PEG tube , which is used for Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy.

Highyeild:

Insertion of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube enhances nutritional and functional outcome in patients unable to maintain oral nutritional intake A schematic diagram of percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy insertion. A standard endoscopy is performed to ensure that there are no contraindications to gastrostomy insertion. The stomach is insufflated with air and a direct percutaneous needle puncture made at a point where the stomach abuts the abdominal wall. Lignocaine is infused on withdrawal (a). A trochar is inserted and a wire passed into the stomach, which can be caught with a snare (b). The scope is withdrawn, pulling the wire out through the mouth, at which point it is attached to the gastrostomy tube (c). The gastrostomy is pulled through into the stomach and out through the track created by the trochar insertion (d).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Orogastric tube image is given below. Option: C. Chest tube drainage system is given below. Option: D. Flatus tube insertion

questions.text: A 45 year old male presented to ER in Altered sensorium & hematemesis for 1 day. He has been a known alcoholic for 20 years with the last binge episode 1 week back. USG shows Liver altered echotexture WITH MILD PORTAL VEIN DILATATION. CT brain is normal. He started on Inj. Pan infusion + Antiemetic, what is the NEXT STEP in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Emergency endoscopy to look for Esophageal varices

options.label: B
options.text: Start LACTULOSE for easy passage of stools

options.label: D
options.text: THIAMINE and CHLORDIAZEPOXIDE for withdrawal symptoms

questions.correct_answer: A. Emergency endoscopy to look for Esophageal varices
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Emergency endoscopy to look for Esophageal varices In the above scenarios immediate Emergency endoscopy to look for Esophageal varices should be the next step in management as the patient is chronic alcoholic and presenting with hematemesis.

Highyeild:

Management of bleeding oesophageal varices Blood transfusion Correct coagulopathy Oesophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube) Drug therapy (terlipressin) Endoscopic sclerotherapy or banding Assess portal vein patency (Doppler ultrasound or CT) Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunts (TIPSS) Surgery Portosystemic shunts Splenectomy and gastric devascularisation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Start LACTULOSE for easy passage of stools is not the next immediate step of management here. Immediate management is to stop bleeding from varices. Option: C. CSF analysis has no role in the above patient. Option: D. THIAMINE and CHLORDIAZEPOXIDE for withdrawal symptoms is given once the patient is stabilized from bleeding esophageal varices.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for GIST:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nestin Nestin is not a marker of GIST. It is used for glioblastomas.

Highyeild:

GASTROINTESTINAL STROMAL TUMORS (GIST) Arise from intestinal pacemaker cells of cajal. Most common site- stomach. Clinical features Most common presentation- Upper GI Hemorrhage. Immunohistochemistry of GIST CD117/C-KIT- Most common, seen in >90% of GIST. CD34 DOG1- Most specific marker for GIST. PDGF alpha mutation. Succinyl dehydrogenase B- seen in patients with carney’s triad. This mutation leads to primary resistance to imatinib.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A, B, C. All these are markers of GIST.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Wilms tumour?

options.label: A
options.text: Usually presents within 5 years of age

options.label: B
options.text: Most common presentation is an abdominal mass

options.label: C
options.text: 95% of patients live long term with surgery and chemo

options.label: D
options.text: Metastasis to lung is late and rare

questions.correct_answer: D. Metastasis to lung is late and rare
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Metastasis to lung is late and rare Metastasis to lung is late and rare is a false statement. It is the most common site of metastasis in Wilms’ tumor.

Highyeild:

WILM’S TUMOR Most common pediatric renal malignancy. Second most common abdominal malignancy. Age of onset- 2 to 5 years. Bilateral. Familial variants are- Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome. Denys drash syndrome. WAGR syndrome. Clinical features Hematuria Abdominal mass which rarely crosses midline. IOC- CECT- Peripheral calcification. Management Chemosensitive Radiosensitive.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Usually presents within 5 years of age is a true statement. Option: B. Most common presentation is an abdominal mass is also a true statement. Option: C. 95% of patients live long term with surgery and chemo is also a true statement.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with recurrent episodes of right flank pain, hematuria, and a history of urinary tract infections. Urine analysis shows alkaline urine with a pH of 8.0. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Triple phosphate stones Coffin lid type of stones, in alkaline ph are seen in proteus infection. These are called as triple phosphate stones STRUVITE/STAGHORN STONES Radio opaque in nature. Seen in alkaline urine. Rectangular/coffin lid appearance. Associated with urea splitting organisms i.e. proteus. Also known as triple phosphate stones. Recurrent triple phosphate stones- medical management with aceto-hydroxamic acid.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B- Calcium oxalate stones are formed in acidic urine. Option: C- Uric acid stones are also formed in acidic/non infected urine. Option: D- Ammonium urate stones are radiolucent stones associated with laxative abuse.

questions.text: What is the color code in trauma triage for patients with life threatening conditions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Red Color code in trauma triage for patients with life threatening conditions is Red.

Highyeild:

TRIAGE Triage categories. Priority Colour Medical need Clinical status First (1) Red Immediate Critical, but likely to survive if treatment given early Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive if treatment given within hours Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days Last (0) Black Unsalvageable Not breathing, pulseless, so severely injured that no medical care is likely to help

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B- Green category patients are stable patients , likely to survive even if treatment is delayed for hours to days. Option: C- Black category are pulseless patients and no medical care is likely to help these patients. Option: D- Yellow category patients are critical patients, who are likely to survive if treatment is given within hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in primary survey of trauma:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NCCT head NCCT head is not done as a primary survey in Trauma patient. The primary survey aims to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first and follows cABCDE.

Highyeild:

PRIMARY SURVEY ABCD rule A- Airway management. (Cervical spine followed by airway). B- Breathing management. C- Circulation. D- Disability management. SECONDARY SURVEY Detailed survery, look everywhere. TERTIARY SURVERY When trauma patient is extubated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B- Chest X-ray can be done as an adjunct to primary survey in trauma patient. Option: C- Intubation is a part of the airway management in case of trauma patient. Option: D- If a patient has pneumothorax/ hemothorax ICD tube is placed as part of primary survery in trauma patient.

questions.text: Patient with a road traffic accident presented to ER with head trauma. He is conscious and in altered sensorium (GCS 10). He complains of a severe headache associated with nausea. His one pupil is dilated and non-reactive. What would be the management?

options.label: B
options.text: Observe and serial monitoring in the ICU

options.label: C
options.text: Osmotic diuresis to decrease intracranial pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Anticoagulants to prevent further clotting of blood

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate surgical evacuation CT shows biconvex appearance which indicates extradural hematoma. In these patients first management will be Immediate surgical evacuation

Highyeild:

EXTRADURAL HEMATOMA Vessel involved- Middle meningeal artery. Clinical feature Lucid interval- Perior of normal consciousness between 2 episodes of impaired consciousness IOC- NCCT- Biconvex/lens shaped hemorrhage. Management Craniotomy/Burr hole. Indications for craniotomy in EDH >30 cc clot size. >5 mm midline shift. >1.5 mm thickness.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B,C,D- All other options can be done in supportive management but immediate and best management will be option A.

questions.text: Which of the following radiological interventions are used in the management of thoracic aortic aneurysm?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stenting Endovascular stenting is the radiological interventions used in the management of thoracic aortic aneurysm.

Highyeild:

INDICATION OF SURGICAL MANAGEMENT OF THORACO ABDOMINAL ANEURYSM In all symptomatic patients including patients with aortic valve insufficiency. Asymptomatic patients with Ascending diameter- 5.5 cm (critical diameter). Descending diameter- 6 cm. Marfan syndrome- 4.5-5 cm.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A,B,D. All other options have no role in management of thoracic aortic aneurysm.
